results.title: How to play cricket by Don Bradman
results.brief_description: This unique film was first produced in England in 1934 with the script written and spoken by Don Bradman. It has been updated with comments by Sir Donald, filmed at his home in Adelaide in May 1993. Provides a rare opportunity for cricket lovers to study the master batsman’s technique in detail, and is an invaluable coaching aid to any aspiring cricketer. Bradman’s test match career was an outstanding example of sporting brilliance; his career total of runs was 6,996 with an average of 99.9, including 29 centuries. Aggression, initiative and improvisation were the hallmarks of his playing and this footage, filmed on the London Cricket Ground in 1934, captures his style perfectly, shows the complete shot and stroke broken down into successive movements and as such provides an invaluable visual description of how to achieve maximum effectiveness and efficiency of movements when batting in a game.

results.title: How to paint like a professional: a complete guide to interior painting.
results.brief_description: A practical guide to handy tips and techniques to achieve a professional interior painting job in your home. Terms like acrylic, enamel, pigment and sealer are clearly explained. Advice is given on the choice of paint, roller and brush, surface preparation, patching cracks, protecting floors and furniture, paint application, cleaning up after the job and storage of excess paint.

results.title: How to organise your own music event (PC)
results.creator_credit: Diane Robbie, Malcolm Smith, Rory Sutton, Global Vision, AUSMUSIC and Songlines Music Aboriginal Corporation
results.brief_description: Organise your own musical performance with the assistance of Rocky the Roadie. The CD ROM covers all details in the organisation of a musical performance, including budgeting, choosing the right venue, promotion and fundraising. The CD is based on a module ‘How to Organise Your Own Music Event’, which is part of AUSMUSIC’s Certificate 2 in Music Industry Skills. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Multimedia PC with 486 DX2/66 or higher, 640x480 display with 256 colors, 8 MB RAM, 16MB of free hard drive space, 4 speed CD ROM drive, Microsoft Windows 3.1 or a later version, and Video For Windows. A 140 page student workbook plus teacher notes accompanies the CD ROM and provides an overview to the piece as well as a glossary of terms, references and useful contacts.

results.title: How to negotiate a great salary package
results.brief_description: What this video lacks in glamorous production values, it more than makes up for in practical tips to negotiate the salary package you want from your employer. The program is in two segments, the first presented by Judy Rose who is experienced in negotiation skills. The second segment is presented by Mike Taylor of Prime Time Financial Counsellors who gives sound financial advice on options within salary packages. Produced for the Australian Institute of Training and Development.

results.title: How to marry a millionaire (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jean Negulesco, Nunnally Johnson and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Marilyn”.
Marilyn Monroe, Betty Grable and Lauren Bacall star as three fashion models in search of millionaire husbands. They pool their resources and rent an expensive penthouse with mixed results. Marilyn Monroe gives an excellent performance as a near-sighted beauty who won’t wear her glasses in public.

results.title: How to marry a millionaire
results.creator_credit: Jean Negulesco, Nunnally Johnson and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Marilyn”.
Lauren Bacall, Betty Grable and Marilyn Monroe are three glamorous models on the lookout for a rich man. Pooling their funds, they decide to rent a luxurious Manhattan penthouse in order to lure their catch. Things are not what they appear to be as two of them fall in love with “poor men.” In the attempt to stop each other from marrying the wrong man, the threesome give their best performances. Utimately, it is love and not money which influences their choices. This film is a must see for lovers of Marilyn Monroe’s quirky and individualistic comedy style.

results.title: How to manage the boss
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz Jr, BNA Communications and Ameron
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Manager and the Organization”.
The subordinate must be able to “read” the boss, to be able to communicate, to prevent “surprises” - problems and crises that could have been anticipated. Bosses need support from the staff, which if given will augment personal effectiveness. Narrated by Peter Drucker.

results.title: How to make the organization work for you
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz Jr, BNA Communications and Ameron
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Manager and the Organization”.
Rules, procedures and good manners are essential, but flexibility is needed. No organisation can operate solely “by the book”. Accomplishment should be the aim, not solely promotion. Outside interests should be developed as a buffer against possible disappointments in the later stages of one’s career. Narrated by Peter Drucker.

results.title: How to make the famous pisco sour
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
‘Pisco Sour’ represents a shift beyond earlier works in its dense layering of subject-matter and imagery. Initiated in Australia and completed in Japan, the work draws upon the core imagery of a bullock dray, a male figure in silhouette, a Japanese mask and a bottle of Pisco Sour. These appear in varied permutations alongside other seemingly random images to form a series of telescopic views (screens within screens). Verbal narrative and textual statement create a sense of tension whilst suggesting that history and meaning are never fixed. The work presents something of a conundrum, its title a metaphoric recipe for the potential ‘souring’ of things.

Produced with the assistance of the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.
